thread.title: U-M vs. Maryland moving to noon because of hurricane
thread.title_full: U-M vs. Maryland moving to noon because of hurricane

title: U-M vs. Maryland moving to noon because of hurricane
text:
Facebook Email Twitter Google+ LinkedIn Pinterest U-M vs. Maryland moving to noon because of hurricane After a few days of worry over Hurricane Joaquin, it appears Michigan's Saturday game against Maryland will move -- eight hours earlier. The Big Ten Post to Facebook U-M vs. Maryland moving to noon because of hurricane After a few days of worry over Hurricane Joaquin, it appears Michigan's Saturday game against Maryland will move -- eight hours earlier. The Big Ten Check out this story on WZZM13.com: http://on.freep.com/1FIvGlR Cancel Send A link has been sent to your friend's email address. Posted! A link has been posted to your Facebook feed. 17 To find out more about Facebook commenting please read the Conversation Guidelines and FAQs U-M vs. Maryland moving to noon because of hurricane Mark Snyder, Detroit Free Press 1:32 p.m. EDT October 1, 2015 Forecasters at the National Hurricane Center expect that Hurricane Joaquin will strengthen to a Category 4 storm by early Friday morning. Michigan Wolverines fans cheer at Rice-Eccles Stadium. (Photo: Jeffrey Swinger USA TODAY Sports) 81 CONNECT 27 TWEET LINKEDIN 17 COMMENT EMAIL MORE 
Michigan's Saturday game against Maryland will move eight hours earlier because of Hurricane Joaquin. 
The Big Ten Network still will broadcast the game, which will start at noon instead of 8 p.m. 
"The weather experts are still dealing with uncertain probabilities for the course of Hurricane Joaquin," U-M interim athletic director Jim Hackett said in a released statement. "Thus we remain vigilant on developments and will err on the side of safety for all participants and fans." 
The threat of the hurricane, which is still projected to be well south of Maryland on Saturday night, had officials looking for a better option . As U-M coach Jim Harbaugh said today, the discussions were in Maryland's court . The Terrapins certainly were not willing to give up an expected sellout. 
Maryland athletic director Kevin Anderson released a statement, as well: "Our foremost priority is the safety and well-being of both teams, fans attending the game and staff. Our collective decision in working with the University of Michigan and the Big Ten Conference was to kick off as early as possible because of the unpredictable nature of Hurricane Joaquin. In addition, those participating, working and attending the game would not have to travel in the evening in potentially dangerous conditions.‚Äù 
Now there will be two games on the BTN at noon: Michigan vs. Maryland and Minnesota vs. Northwestern. Fans can go to btn.com/gamefinder to see which game is on which channel in their area. 
The shuffle also is changing the kickoff time for Nebraska at Illinois, which now will kick off at 4:02 p.m. Eastern time, instead of 3:30 p.m.
